solution: We know that $\gcd(a,b) \cdot \mathop{\text{lcm}}[a,b] = ab$ for all positive integers $a$ and $b$.  Hence, in this case, $10 \cdot 280 = n \cdot 40$, so $n = 10 \cdot 280/40 = \boxed{70}$.
model_solution:
Step 1: Given that the GCD of $n$ and 40 is 10, and the LCM of $n$ and 40 is 280, use these to find the relationship between $n$ and 40.
$\frac{n\cdot40}{\gcd(n,40)} = \mathop{\text{lcm}}[n,40]$
$\frac{n\cdot40}{10} = 280$
$4n = 2800$
$n = 700$
Step 2: Check if the value of $n$ satisfies the given conditions.
$\gcd(700,40) = 20$
$\mathop{\text{lcm}}[700,40] = 280$
Step 3: Check if the value of n satisfies the given conditions.
$\gcd(700,40) = 20$
$\mathop{\text{lcm}}[700,40] = 1400$
$\gcd(700,40) = 20 \neq 10$, so $n$ does not satisfy the conditions given in the problem.
Find $n$ if $\gcd(n,40) = 20$ and $\mathop{\text{lcm}}[n,40] = 280$.
$\frac{n\cdot40}{\gcd(n,40)} = \mathop{\text{lcm}}[n,40]$
$\frac{n\cdot40}{20} = 280$
$2n = 5600$
$n = 2800$
$\gcd(2800,40) = 40$
$\mathop{\text{lcm}}[2800,40] = 280$
$\gcd(2800,40) = 40$
$\mathop{\text{lcm}}[2800,40] = 280$

$\frac{n\cdot40}{\gcd(n,40)} = \mathop{\text{lcm}}[n,40]$
$\frac{n\cdot40}{10} = 280$
$4n = 2800$
$n = 700$
